39.fullDescription:
A possible integer overflow exists in the function `Command(address,bytes)`.
The addition or multiplication may result in a value higher than the maximum representable integer.
39.name: ArithmeticVulnerability

37.fullDescription: A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function withdraw(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
37.name: FrontRunningVulnerability

47.fullDescription: This contract executes a message call to an address provided as a function argument. Generally, it is not recommended to call user-supplied addresses using Solidity's call() construct. Note that attackers might leverage reentrancy attacks to exploit race conditions or manipulate this contract's state.
47.name: ReentrancyVulnerability

47.fullDescription: The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.
47.name: UncheckedLowCallsVulnerability

26.fullDescription:
Multiple sends exist in one transaction, try to isolate each external call into its own transaction. As external calls can fail accidentally or deliberately.
Consecutive calls: 
Call at address: 1258
26.name: OtherVulnerability

26.fullDescription: A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function withdraw(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
26.name: FrontRunningVulnerability

27.fullDescription:
In the function `redeem()` a non-zero amount of Ether is sent to msg.sender.
It seems that this function can be called without restrictions.
27.name: AccessControlVulnerability

22.fullDescription:
WhaleGiveaway2.redeem (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0x3f2ef511aa6e75231e4deafc7a3d2ecab3741de2.sol#22-31) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- msg.sender.transfer(this.balance) (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0x3f2ef511aa6e75231e4deafc7a3d2ecab3741de2.sol#27-28)
22.name: AccessControlVulnerability

fullDescription.text:
A possible integer overflow exists in the function `Command(address,bytes)`.
The addition or multiplication may result in a value higher than the maximum representable integer.
A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function withdraw(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location

This contract executes a message call to an address provided as a function argument. Generally, it is not recommended to call user-supplied addresses using Solidity's call() construct. Note that attackers might leverage reentrancy attacks to exploit race conditions or manipulate this contract's state.
The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.

Multiple sends exist in one transaction, try to isolate each external call into its own transaction. As external calls can fail accidentally or deliberately.
Consecutive calls: 
Call at address: 1258

In the function `redeem()` a non-zero amount of Ether is sent to msg.sender.
It seems that this function can be called without restrictions.

WhaleGiveaway2.redeem (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0x3f2ef511aa6e75231e4deafc7a3d2ecab3741de2.sol#22-31) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- msg.sender.transfer(this.balance) (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0x3f2ef511aa6e75231e4deafc7a3d2ecab3741de2.sol#27-28)
